messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Modal logic, fundamentally

Paper Abstract: Abstract Non-classical generalizations of classical modal logic have been developed in the contexts of constructive mathematics and natural language semantics. In this paper, we discuss a general approach to the semantics of non-classical modal logics via algebraic representation theorems. We begin with complete lattices L𝐿L equipped with an antitone operation ¬\neg sending 111 to 00, a completely multiplicative operation □□\Box, and a completely additive operation ◇◇\Diamond. Such lattice expansions can be represented by means of a set X𝑋X together with binary relations ⊲⊲\vartriangleleft, R𝑅R, and Q𝑄Q, satisfying some first-order conditions, used to represent (L,¬)𝐿(L,\neg), □□\Box, and ◇◇\Diamond, respectively. Indeed, any lattice L𝐿L equipped with such a ¬\neg, a multiplicative □□\Box, and an additive ◇◇\Diamond embeds into the lattice of propositions of a frame (X,⊲,R,Q)𝑋⊲𝑅𝑄(X,\vartriangleleft,R,Q). Building on our recent study of fundamental logic, we focus on the case where ¬\neg is dually self-adjoint (a≤¬b𝑎𝑏a\leq\neg b implies b≤¬a𝑏𝑎b\leq\neg a) and ◇​¬a≤¬□​a◇𝑎□𝑎\Diamond\neg a\leq\neg\Box a. In this case, the representations can be constrained so that R=Q𝑅𝑄R=Q, i.e., we need only add a single relation to (X,⊲)𝑋⊲(X,\vartriangleleft) to represent both □□\Box and ◇◇\Diamond. Using these results, we prove that a system of fundamental modal logic is sound and complete with respect to an elementary class of bi-relational structures (X,⊲,R)𝑋⊲𝑅(X,\vartriangleleft,R).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Fundamental logic is decidable",
        "Duality for bounded lattices (1993)",
        "Canonical extensions and relational representations of lattices with negation",
        "Basic logic and the cube of its extensions",
        "Positive modal logic beyond distributivity",
        "Choice-free Stone duality",
        "Lattice Theory",
        "Intuitionism and the modal logic of vagueness",
        "Models for normal intuitionistic modal logics",
        "Modelling informational entropy",
        "Categories: How I learned to stop worrying and love two sorts",
        "A fresh perspective on canonical extensions for bounded lattices",
        "Quantum logics",
        "Positive modal logic beyond distributivity: duality, preservation and completeness",
        "Negative modal operators in intuitionistic logic",
        "Negation as a modal operator",
        "Negation in the light of modal logic",
        "Star and perp: Two treatments of negation",
        "Generalized ortho negation",
        "A comparative study of various model-theoretic treatments of negation: a history of formal negation",
        "Negation in the context of gaggle theory",
        "Relational representation theorems for general lattices with negations",
        "Relational representation theorems for lattices with negations: A survey",
        "On modal logic with an intuitionistic base",
        "Symbolic Logic: An Introduction",
        "Natural deduction rules for obligation",
        "Generalized Kripke frames",
        "Untersuchungen über das logische Schließen",
        "Die Widerspruchsfreiheit der reinen Zahlentheorie",
        "Zur intuitionistischen Arithmetik und Zahlentheorie",
        "Morphisms and duality for polarities and lattices with operators (2019)",
        "Semantic analysis of orthologic",
        "Discrete duality for lattices with modal operators",
        "Representation of lattices with modal operators in two-sorted frames",
        "Die formalen Regeln der intuitionistischen Logik I",
        "Possibility frames and forcing for modal logic (2015)",
        "Possibility semantics",
        "Compatibility and accessibility: lattice representations for semantics of non-classical and modal logics",
        "A fundamental non-classical logic",
        "Preconditionals (2024)",
        "The orthologic of epistemic modals",
        "Boolean Algebras with Operators. Part I.",
        "Human abilities and dynamic modalities",
        "B-frame duality",
        "Cut elimination and word problems for varieties of lattices",
        "Lattice-based modal algebras and modal logics",
        "A natural representation of bounded lattices",
        "Compatibility between modal operators in distributive modal logic (2023)",
        "On the algebraization of some Gentzen systems",
        "A topological representation theory for lattices",
        "Consistency, completeness and negation",
        "Constructive modal logics I",
        "A general relational semantics of propositional logic: Axiomatization"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Modal logic, fundamentally, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
